Paper 2 AS Level Structured Questions

No additional materials are needed.  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 418, 230, 434]]<|/det|>
## INSTRUCTIONS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 435, 808, 559]]<|/det|>
INSTRUCTIONS- Answer all questions.- Use a black or dark blue pen. You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs.- Write your name, centre number and candidate number in the boxes at the top of the page.- Write your answer to each question in the space provided.- Do not use an erasable pen or correction fluid.- Do not write on any bar codes.- You may use a calculator.- You should show all your working and use appropriate units.  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 588, 220, 602]]<|/det|>
## INFORMATION  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 604, 728, 635]]<|/det|>
INFORMATION- The total mark for this paper is 60.- The number of marks for each question or part question is shown in brackets [ ].

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[87, 73, 126, 88]]<|/det|>
## Data  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 102, 688, 530]]<|/det|>
acceleration of free fall \(g = 9.81 \text{m s}^{- 2}\) speed of light in free space \(c = 3.00 \times 10^{8} \text{m s}^{- 1}\) elementary charge \(e = 1.60 \times 10^{- 19} \text{C}\) unified atomic mass unit \(1 \text{u} = 1.66 \times 10^{- 27} \text{kg}\) rest mass of proton \(m_{\mathrm{p}} = 1.67 \times 10^{- 27} \text{kg}\) rest mass of electron \(m_{\mathrm{e}} = 9.11 \times 10^{- 31} \text{kg}\) Avogadro constant \(N_{\mathrm{A}} = 6.02 \times 10^{23} \text{mol}^{- 1}\) molar gas constant \(R = 8.31 \text{J K}^{- 1} \text{mol}^{- 1}\) Boltzmann constant \(k = 1.38 \times 10^{- 23} \text{J K}^{- 1}\) gravitational constant \(G = 6.67 \times 10^{- 11} \text{N m}^{2} \text{kg}^{- 2}\) permittivity of free space \(\epsilon_{0} = 8.85 \times 10^{- 12} \text{F m}^{- 1}\) \(\left(\frac{1}{4\pi\epsilon_{0}}\right) = 8.99 \times 10^{9} \text{m F}^{- 1})\) Planck constant \(h = 6.63 \times 10^{- 34} \text{J s}\) Stefan- Boltzmann constant \(\sigma = 5.67 \times 10^{- 8} \text{W m}^{- 2} \text{K}^{- 4}\)  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 565, 168, 581]]<|/det|>
## Formulae

Doppler effect for sound waves

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 793, 228, 809]]<|/det|>

resistors in parallel

\[s = ut + \frac{1}{2} at^{2}\] \[\nu^{2} = u^{2} + 2as\]

\[\Delta p = \rho g\Delta h\]

\[f_{0} = \frac{f_{s}V}{\nu\pm\nu_{s}}\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[440, 757, 551, 777]]<|/det|>
\[I = A n v q\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[440, 789, 606, 809]]<|/det|>
\[R = R_{1} + R_{2} + \ldots\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[430, 819, 613, 853]]<|/det|>
\[\frac{1}{R} = \frac{1}{R_{1}} +\frac{1}{R_{2}} +\ldots\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 73, 99, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 73, 146, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 72, 737, 91]]<|/det|>
In the following list, underline **all** quantities that are SI base quantities.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[256, 102, 740, 121]]<|/det|>
charge electric current force time

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 102, 920, 121]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 134, 146, 152]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 133, 920, 168]]<|/det|>
Under certain conditions, the distance \(s\) moved in a straight line by an object in time \(t\) is given by

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[462, 177, 536, 198]]<|/det|>
\[s = \frac{1}{2} at^2\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 211, 490, 229]]<|/det|>
where \(a\) is the acceleration of the object.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 242, 902, 260]]<|/det|>
State **two** conditions under which the above expression applies to the motion of the object.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 272, 173, 291]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 303, 173, 322]]<|/det|>
<label>2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 320, 920, 338]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 350, 146, 369]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 350, 920, 384]]<|/det|>
The variation with time \(t\) of the velocity \(\nu\) of a car that is moving in a straight line is shown in Fig. 1.1.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[247, 394, 745, 682]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 700, 532, 719]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 1.1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 72, 183, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 71, 920, 104]]<|/det|>
Compare, qualitatively, the acceleration of the car at time \(t = 8.0 \text{s}\) and at time \(t = 14.0 \text{s}\) in terms of:

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 117, 324, 135]]<|/det|>
● magnitude

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 211, 311, 228]]<|/det|>
● direction.

<mark>[2]

<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 318, 779, 337]]<|/det|>
Determine the magnitude of the acceleration of the car at time \(t = 4.0 \text{s}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 488, 920, 507]]<|/det|>
<form>acceleration = ............................................ $\text{ms}^{-2}$

Determine the magnitude of the displacement of the car from X at time \(t = 12.0 \text{s}\).

<form>displacement = .................................................... $m$

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 144, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 72, 432, 89]]<|/det|>
The sphere has a mass of \(4.0 \text{kg}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 102, 920, 135]]<|/det|>
Calculate the total resistive force acting on the sphere at the instant when its acceleration is \(1.9 \text{m s}^{-2}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[448, 272, 920, 291]]<|/det|>
<form>resistive force = .................................................... N [2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[843, 303, 920, 320]]<|/det|>
<mark>[Total: 8]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 94, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>3</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 756, 89]]<|/det|>
A vertical rod is fixed to the horizontal surface of a table, as shown in Fig. 3.1.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[336, 98, 660, 260]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[406, 275, 591, 294]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 3.1 (not to scale)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 306, 680, 325]]<|/det|>
A spring of mass \(7.5 \text{g}\) is able to slide along the full length of the rod.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 338, 920, 388]]<|/det|>
The spring is first pushed against the surface of the table so that it has an initial compression of \(2.1 \text{cm}\). The spring is then suddenly released so that it leaves the surface of the table with a kinetic energy of \(0.048 \text{J}\) and then moves up the rod.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 400, 920, 450]]<|/det|>
Assume that the spring obeys Hooke's law and that the initial elastic potential energy of the compressed spring is equal to the kinetic energy of the spring as it leaves the surface of the table. Air resistance is negligible.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 462, 146, 480]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 462, 920, 495]]<|/det|>
By using the initial elastic potential energy of the compressed spring, calculate its spring constant.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[437, 647, 920, 666]]<|/det|>
<form>spring constant = .................................................. $\text{Nm}^{-1}$

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 679, 148, 696]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 678, 727, 696]]<|/det|>
Calculate the speed of the spring as it leaves the surface of the table.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[512, 848, 920, 866]]<|/det|>
<form>speed = ................................................. $\text{ms}^{-1}$

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[895, 848, 920, 866]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 144, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 72, 918, 104]]<|/det|>
The spring rises to its maximum height up the rod from the surface of the table. This causes the gravitational potential energy of the spring to increase by 0.039 J.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 117, 181, 135]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 117, 920, 150]]<|/det|>
Calculate, for this movement of the spring, the increase in height of the spring after leaving the surface of the table.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[418, 288, 920, 307]]<|/det|>
<form>increase in height = ....................................................... m [2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 319, 181, 338]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 319, 853, 338]]<|/det|>
Calculate the average frictional force exerted by the rod on the spring as it rises.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[376, 473, 920, 492]]<|/det|>
<form>average frictional force = .................................................... N [2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 505, 146, 523]]<|/det|>
<label>(d)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 504, 920, 567]]<|/det|>
The rod is replaced by another rod that exerts negligible frictional force on the moving spring. The initial compression \(x\) of the spring is now varied in order to vary the maximum increase in height \(\Delta h\) of the spring after leaving the surface of the table. Assume that the spring obeys Hooke's law for all compressions.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 583, 920, 615]]<|/det|>
On Fig. 3.2, sketch a graph to show the variation with \(x\) of \(\Delta h\). Numerical values are not required.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[354, 625, 640, 797]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 812, 534, 831]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3.2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 828, 920, 846]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[833, 858, 920, 876]]<|/det|>
<mark>[Total: 10]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 97, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>4</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 146, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 72, 920, 106]]<|/det|>
A ball Y moves along a horizontal frictionless surface and collides with a ball Z, as illustrated in the views from above in Fig. 4.1 and Fig. 4.2.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 112, 880, 242]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[180, 270, 366, 288]]<|/det|>
BEFORE COLLISION

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[621, 270, 792, 288]]<|/det|>
AFTER COLLISION

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[183, 305, 368, 323]]<|/det|>
Fig. 4.1 (not to scale)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[631, 305, 813, 323]]<|/det|>
Fig. 4.2 (not to scale)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 336, 683, 355]]<|/det|>
Ball Y has a mass of \(0.25\mathrm{kg}\) and initially moves along a line PQ.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 352, 541, 370]]<|/det|>
Ball Z has a mass \(m_{\mathrm{Z}}\) and is initially stationary.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 382, 920, 415]]<|/det|>
After the collision, ball Y has a final velocity of \(3.7 \text{m s}^{-1}\) at an angle of \(27^{\circ}\) to line PQ and ball Z has a final velocity of \(5.5 \text{m s}^{-1}\) at an angle of \(44^{\circ}\) to line PQ.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 429, 181, 448]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 429, 920, 463]]<|/det|>
Calculate the component of the final momentum of ball Y in the direction perpendicular to line PQ.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[354, 600, 920, 618]]<|/det|>
<form>component of momentum = .................................................... $N$ s [2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 631, 181, 650]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 630, 920, 664]]<|/det|>
By considering the component of the final momentum of each ball in the direction perpendicular to line PQ, calculate \(m_{\mathrm{Z}}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[539, 800, 920, 819]]<|/det|>
<form>m_{\mathrm{Z}} = ............................................................ $kg$ [1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 72, 180, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>(iii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 71, 920, 106]]<|/det|>
During the collision, the average force exerted on Y by Z is \(F_{\mathrm{Y}}\) and the average force exerted on Z by Y is \(F_{\mathrm{Z}}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 117, 920, 136]]<|/det|>
Compare the magnitudes and directions of \(F_{\mathrm{Y}}\) and \(F_{\mathrm{Z}}\). Numerical values are not required.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 149, 918, 166]]<|/det|>
magnitudes: ............................................................................................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 180, 920, 197]]<|/det|>
directions: ............................................................................................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 196, 920, 214]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 227, 146, 244]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 227, 920, 259]]<|/det|>
Two blocks, A and B, move directly towards each other along a horizontal frictionless surface, as shown in the view from above in Fig. 4.3.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[331, 272, 665, 312]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[465, 329, 534, 346]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 4.3</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 359, 920, 408]]<|/det|>
The blocks collide perfectly elastically. Before the collision, block A has a speed of \(4 \mathrm{~m} \mathrm{~s}^{- 1}\) and block B has a speed of \(6 \mathrm{~m} \mathrm{~s}^{- 1}\). After the collision, block B moves back along its original path with a speed of \(2 \mathrm{~m} \mathrm{~s}^{- 1}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 421, 556, 439]]<|/det|>
Calculate the speed of block A after the collision.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[514, 528, 920, 547]]<|/det|>
<form>speed = .................................................... $\mathrm{m} \mathrm{s}^{-1}$

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[843, 559, 920, 576]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[843, 560, 920, 578]]<|/det|>
<mark>[Total: 6]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 97, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>5</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 146, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 72, 920, 106]]<|/det|>
A beam of vertically polarised light is incident normally on a polarising filter, as shown in Fig. 5.1.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[220, 112, 774, 234]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[465, 252, 532, 270]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 5.1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 282, 183, 301]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 282, 920, 316]]<|/det|>
The transmission axis of the filter is initially vertical. The filter is then rotated through an angle of \(360^{\circ}\) while the plane of the filter remains perpendicular to the beam.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 329, 920, 363]]<|/det|>
On Fig. 5.2, sketch a graph to show the variation of the intensity of the light in the transmitted beam with the angle through which the transmission axis is rotated.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[195, 371, 801, 526]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[465, 542, 534, 560]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 5.2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 558, 920, 576]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 588, 181, 606]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 588, 920, 637]]<|/det|>
The intensity of the light in the incident beam is \(7.6 \text{W} \text{m}^{-2}\). When the transmission axis of the filter is at angle \(\theta\) to the vertical, the light intensity of the transmitted beam is \(4.2 \text{W} \text{m}^{-2}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 650, 346, 668]]<|/det|>
Calculate angle \(\theta\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[554, 774, 892, 793]]<|/det|>
<form>\(\theta =\) ....................................................\(\text{°}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 71, 920, 106]]<|/det|>
A beam of light of wavelength \(4.3 \times 10^{- 7} \text{m}\) is incident normally on a diffraction grating in air, as shown in Fig. 5.3.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 339, 920, 374]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 72, 920, 106]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[487, 272, 920, 291]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 303, 920, 337]]<|/det|>
A battery of electromotive force (e.m.f.) \(E\) and negligible internal resistance is connected in series with a fixed resistor and a light-dependent resistor (LDR), as shown in Fig. 6.1.

<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 495, 532, 514]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 526, 920, 560]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 133, 920, 173]]<|/det|>
A nucleus of thorium-230 ( \(^{230}_{90}\mathrm {Th})\) decays in stages, by emitting \(\alpha \text {-particles}\) and \(\beta ^{-}\) particles, to form a nucleus of lead-206 ( \(^{206}_{82}\mathrm {Pb})\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 186, 920, 234]]<|/det|>
